About Me
Monel‚Äôs Compass Bio
1. Introduction
Hi, I‚Äôm Monel, a 36-year-old Korean-American naturopathic doctor and performance artist living in the Pacific Northwest. I speak Korean, English, and conversational Spanish and German. My days flow between patient care, artistic exploration, and outdoor adventures in the forested trails nearby.
2. Connection Goals
I‚Äôm seeking a life partner‚Äîsomeone who shares the desire to build a biological family rooted in love, play, and shared growth. I‚Äôm in the PST timezone with a flexible schedule, and I most enjoy connecting through video calls and in-person meetups where energy and presence can be felt more fully.
3. Core Values
Integrity: living in alignment with my words and actions.
Kindness: leading with compassion toward myself and others.
Creativity: approaching life as an ongoing artistic and healing process.
4. Interests & Activities
I find joy in contact improvisation dance, hiking, and backpacking in nature. I love exploring somatics and interoception, and I often unwind by experimenting with new recipes and tasting unfamiliar flavors. Movement, sensory exploration, and curiosity are my gateways into connection‚Äîwith myself and others.
5. Personality & Thinking Style
I think emotionally, creatively, and logically, often weaving all three into how I approach life. While I identify loosely as an ENFP, I see personality as fluid and context-dependent. My humor leans toward playful and introspective, and I value conversations that dance between depth and delight.
6. Lifestyle & Preferences
I live a healthy, balanced lifestyle‚Äîexercise daily, eat mostly whole foods, and rarely drink or smoke. I currently rent a home with two close friends, and I‚Äôm hoping to own a place next year. I work a hybrid 9-5 resident position at a clinic, blending structure with flexibility.
7. Health & Self-Improvement
I‚Äôve been dedicated to therapy and self-growth since I was 16, exploring modalities like Internal Family Systems and deep self-inquiry. My current focus is cultivating self-love and integration‚Äîlearning to meet each inner part with acceptance and curiosity.
8. Romantic Relationships
I‚Äôm pansexual, though I tend to lean toward the middle of the Kinsey scale (2.5). My love languages are quality time and physical touch, expressed through presence, playfulness, and care. I hope to co-create a partnership that supports mutual evolution, embodied intimacy, and a shared dream of family life.
9. Ideal Connections
I feel most at ease with embodied, grounded people who are self-aware, intuitive, and comfortable in their own skin. I‚Äôm drawn to those who value clear communication, vulnerability, and emotional honesty‚Äîpeople who meet life with both reverence and humor.
10. Altruistic & Community Values
I care deeply about environmental sustainability and holistic healthcare access. I aspire to contribute to communities that prioritize wellbeing, ecological awareness, and equitable systems of care.
11. Conversation Starters
What is your inner dialogue like?
How are you connected to your body?
What creative endeavors help you feel most alive?

About Me
Thoughtful, intellectually curious, and ethically driven, I value deep connections, emotional stability, and personal growth. I enjoy philosophy, science, nature, and mindful physical activity, living simply while prioritizing honesty and meaningful relationships.
Detailed Description
I  speak English and French fluently and I‚Äôm currently in Europe, but I have recently lived in the US (for 4 years) and India (for 6 months). I'm mostly looking for
Collaborations: working together on a joint project that we enjoy. I started Compass, and I'm actively looking for ambassadors to volunteer together and share the platform with their network! We could have meetings and discuss how to reach the people who would benefit from it the most. Regardless, hit me up if you have anything to say about Compass! I'm also happy to work on any other project we find meaningful.
Friendships: mostly to discuss online and share deeper things (see details below).
Life partnership: with a woman who deeply resonates with what I wrote below.
Core Values
Highly stable and non-negotiable guiding principles that shape my worldview, decisions, and moral framework.
Intellectual curiosity with rational integrity: I evaluate beliefs against evidence and enjoy conversations that challenge and expand my thinking.
Ethical responsibility / Utilitarian-leaning ethics: I consciously act to reduce suffering and improve outcomes on a large scale‚Äîthrough causes like animal welfare, climate change, AI safety, and global poverty.
Emotional stability and resilience: I remain calm under stress, self-soothe effectively, and approach conflicts with reason rather than panic or overreaction.
Deep, loving relationships: I thrive in profound 1-on-1 connections where accountability, honesty, and mutual growth are prioritized.
Growth-oriented conflict resolution: I engage in solution-focused dialogue, tolerate relational discomfort, and prioritize repair over avoidance.
Integrity & deliberateness: I aim to live according to my principles and consciously cultivate trust, depth, and clarity during relationships.
Tolerance for differences: I‚Äôm very willing to connect with people who fit more than 70% of these values, embracing trade-offs and growth together.
Lifestyle & Secondary Values
Traits or principles that matter to me, but are negotiable or context-dependent. Mostly applying to life partnerships‚Äînot friendships.
Life Vision & Practicalities:
Geography: I enjoy living in Europe but am open to relocate if circumstances align.
Family: I‚Äôd like 1‚Äì2 children within roughly 5‚Äì10 years, depending on mutual readiness.
Career / lifestyle: I support a partner‚Äôs work and ambitions, as long as we can spend meaningful time together (2+ hours most days).
Financial approach: I live frugally, saving or donating the rest, but am comfortable if my partner spends more on things meaningful to her.
Attachment & Intimacy Needs
Conflict & repair: I notice when someone is hurt, but I do not chase them if they withdraw. I prefer calm, constructive conversations when both sides are ready. Because I'll care about you, I'll express it when I think you may be wrong‚Äîat the same time, I'll always have your back.
Emotional intelligence: I‚Äôm aware of my emotions and take time to process before responding, which helps me stay calm in tense moments. I try to express my feelings honestly, listen carefully to understand others, and take responsibility when I misstep. I believe that, with mutual effort, we can keep strengthening our emotional intelligence and connection as a healthy, securely attached couple.
Emotional expressiveness: More through words, modest body language and thoughtful gifts than grand gestures.
Preferred intimacy style: I enjoy direct and meaningful connections‚Äîlong dedicated conversations over frequent, shallow texts. I seek a monogamous relationship.
Lifestyle Habits & Daily Rhythms:
Dietary choices: Mostly vegan; I strongly value sensitivity to animal well-being.
Sleep & energy patterns: Typically 11pm‚Äì8am; similar routines are a plus.
Exercise & health: Small-group activities several times per week. Open to mental health practices to improve relationships and wellbeing.
Social engagement: Few close friendships; comfortable connecting with more socially active or community-involved partners.
Family engagement: Average.
Minimalism: I live a simple and non-performative life without clutter, in order to focus on what truly matters.
Emotional & Cognitive Style:
Humor: Mix of wit, playful absurdity, and sarcasm.
Tolerance for uncertainty: Comfortable with ambiguity, but appreciate clear plans when possible.
Romantic philosophy: Love grows deliberately; romance and thoughtful gestures (e.g., poems) are enjoyable once fundamental compatibilities are aligned.
Role expectations: Prefer equal partnership, but open to specialization if mutually desired.
Interests & Activities
Activities or pursuits I enjoy but that don‚Äôt define my ethics or essential lifestyle.
Intellectual pursuits: Reading nonfiction, exploring philosophy, science, history, and practical wisdom; hands-on learning through building and fixing things.
Deep conversation: Intense, thoughtful dialogue with like-minded people.
Optimization & personal growth: Exploring methods to improve life, productivity, and learning practices.
Nature & mindfulness: Contemplative walks or time in natural landscapes; pausing to observe wildlife or scenery inspires awe.
Physical activities: Running, biking, swimming, weightlifting‚Äîoften integrated with mindfulness.
Influences
Contents that majorly influenced my worldview.
Books:
Thinking, Fast and Slow - Daniel Kahneman
The Art of Living a Meaningless Existence - Robert Pantano
Le Petit Prince - Antoine de Saint-Exup√©ry
L‚Äô√©tranger - Albert Camus
Existential Physics - Sabine Hossenfelder
The Big Picture - Sean Carroll
Doing Good Better - William MacAskill
Emotional Intelligence - Daniel Goleman
Waking Up - Sam Harris
Deep Work - Cal Newport
Sapiens - Yuval Noah Harari
Being the Change - Peter Kalmus
YouTube channels:
The Pursuit of Wonder
Kurzgesagt
Feel free to send recommendations or discuss any content you like!
About You
To an imperfect extent, I like who I am and what I do, and would like to see it in the people around me. So, I‚Äôm mostly looking for people who identify‚Äîat least partially‚Äîwith the description above and would enjoy the same activities. I believe in growth and potential; so I embrace people who are not there yet (so am I) but have, deep inside, the intention to reach it.
As long as you fit some of the description, relationships, to me, transcend gender, age, culture, financial situation, or any other socio-demographic factors; please reach out to me regardless of your situation if you relate to my personality traits. Locations should not be an issue either (a priori); I‚Äôve had close long-distance friendships which worked beautifully for me.
About Us
I would love to form a close friendship with 3-5 people, and one life partnership with a woman. If you want a shallower connection, that‚Äôs also okay; maybe we can still contribute to each other‚Äôs lives.
I'm also looking for collaboration, whether on Compass or any other project which I would be aligned with.
While some key relationship values, such as depth and trust, grow over time, there is one value which, I believe, should be there from the start: honesty. In this regard, please be honest about your intentions‚Äîwhich may include different types of relationships depending on how it evolves, and that‚Äôs okay.
Things I'm currently exploring and I'd like to discuss with whoever is interested:
Population ethics in utilitarianism (total view vs neutral / person affective, longtermism, What we owe the future from MacAskill)
Moral realism vs anti-realism, the different sub types of anti-realism, mostly constructivism and non-cognitivism (Bertrand Russell, Sean Carroll)
Consciousness, and whether the hard problem is really a problem
Do multidisciplinary research / PhD across science and philosophy
If emotional intelligence, unlike IQ, is context-dependent (one can have high EI with one type of person, and low EI with another), how important is it to have high EI across all contexts? What proportion of EI is objective (high across all contexts)?
Effective altruism
Disclaimers
This document desperately lacks elaboration, emotions, and personal information for privacy reasons. I have no issue sharing about my life story, what I look like, what I feel and think, vulnerability, intimacy, and other personal features in private.
Endorsements

Those are my more specific and consistent hobbies, but (of course) I also enjoy various other random activities, like watching videos and TV shows with others, playing through visual novels with friends while we voice the characters (I quite enjoy doing fun/silly voices), going out for a drink with friends, and just general walking/talking/hanging out.

The ways I prefer to show and receive affection are very similar. I enjoy quality time, physical touch, and a steady stream of witty banter (plus the occasional bite). I love hyping up my partner and listening to your thoughts about the world.

I see conflict as an opportunity for growth, not a fight. We‚Äôre on the same team, trying to understand each other and figure out what needs to be seen. When things get tense, I stay calm and grounded so we can figure it out together.
I don‚Äôt raise my voice during an argument. I‚Äôm not a stoic robot, but there are ways to express yourself while being respectful. I take feedback seriously, especially when it comes from a place of care. I want us to both feel comfortable sharing ways to grow.

about me
Hi! I‚Äôm Emily, a 24-year-old woman looking for a monogamous male life partner. I live near Philadelphia, but am not settled yet.
I center my life around close relationships and doing good for the world. My brain works in optimizey ways, but I also trust intuition, feel deeply, and love being playful.
What‚Äôs noticeable about me in relationships is that I‚Äôm an intense person! I naturally go all in and move fast when aligned with something. I feel profoundly grateful to be alive, so I try to live with maximum agency.
My lifestyle is minimalist and utility based (though not robotic-y!), and this leads me to be very open-minded about how to get things done. I adore unconventional ideas (e.g. I sleep in a sleeping bag on the floor with no pillow), and highly value authenticity and creativity.
Ultimately, my favorite moments are the mundane moments just being present, especially with close friends. And I love when the people in my life balance me to be more spontaneous, accepting, and joyful for the sake of being joyful.

George‚Äôs Date-Me Document
Retired future poker player, current nomadic uncle, aspiring intentional live-r.
In an even earlier lifetime, I was a data scientist and quit my corporate job to play poker. But then, I realized all I did was swap my corporate treadmill for a competitive-gaming exercise bike, and that I hadn't actually solved the incongruence of driving to the gym and taking the elevator to get on an exercise machine to work off all the processed foods I stress ate. So now, I‚Äôm walking outside instead, constantly checking how much longer it‚Äôll be until I‚Äôve reached my step goal for the day.
(To be clear, this is all strictly a metaphor. I've never actually been motivated to consistently go to the gym; I have a very high metabolism that tricked me into thinking I was healthy when I wasn't. Also, my metaphors may need work. Help me please?)
üîç About Me
Name: George
Age: 35
Height: 5‚Äô8
Location: Nomadic (with a temporary home base in the SF Bay Area)
Occupation: Funemployed explorer (aka whatever I want)
Religion: Agnostic but closer to spiritual
I quit my corporate job in 2019 and spent the next few years studying (running programs / developing strategies / memorizing decision trees) and playing poker because I wanted to see how good I could be at something that more matched my skillsets. At the same time, after becoming aware to how much my achievement mindset had driven my life for so long and how I no longer wanted that, I‚Äôve decided that poker will likely just be a way for me to offset costs going forward and not the primary focus of my life. So I've become interested in traveling (seeing the world, meeting cool people, having new experiences), and I was on an extended roadtrip for almost 2 years across the US (primarily through National Parks and secondarily through art museums‚Äîyes, my header picture is from Chihuli in Seattle). More recently, I was in Peru for a month and LOVED it, and I‚Äôm currently embarking on a Europe‚áíAfrica‚áíSE Asia cruise.
Longer term, I know that I'll likely want to be geographically flexible or nomadic. I'm not sure for how long I'll want to travel or if I eventually want to establish a more permanent home (forming a community of likeminded people does interest me intellectually). I'll very likely be interested in having children at some point, because I find children to be wonderful learning beings and I'd like to help with and be a part of that process, but as I've learned over the years, I never truly know what future George wants. No matter how convinced I am at any moment that past George was wrong but NOW present George is completely right, I know it's all a trick. I think.
üïµÔ∏è What I Am Looking For
Relationship Goals:
Open to both monogamy and nonmonogamy: I‚Äôve traditionally only been in monogamous romantic relationships but I‚Äôve grown to appreciate the nonduality of relationships (i.e. a spectrum from acquaintances to more platonic friendships to primary life partner) and realize that our love isn‚Äôt finite. Ultimately, I do expect to be monogamish (if not monogamous), as my energy and interests tend to hyperfixate more than those of most polyamorous people do
Children: Yes please! And hopefully more than 1 (I was an only child)! I ultimately would like to be a stay-at-home parent and would be thrilled if my partner would want to as well, especially for the early years of the children‚Äôs lives
Platonic connections: open and excited about connecting with people even if it doesn‚Äôt lead to ‚Äúmy one true soulmate‚Äù (/whatever the nonmonogamous version of that is)
Ideal Partner:
More motivated by her own desires than those of other people and of society
Chaotic good: rules are only guidelines and I‚Äôd hope that kindness and care for other beings trumps all. But also, some such guidelines hopefully are more important than others (i.e. radical honesty with each other and with our children is near the top)
Adventurous: more inspired by new experiences than by comfortable routines
Neverending mutual teasing (including of ourselves). For example, my college application essay was about the tribulations of growing up short (I was robbed of a storied NBA career by these struggles)
Toni Stark (if she exists) is my ideal
Very ADHD conversations: as you can probably already tell by my liberal use of parentheses, I get distracted easily in my writing, and I can confirm that conversing with me is a similarly disjointed experience
Values:
Curiosity and open-mindedness: relatedly, an understanding that the absence of evidence does not mean the evidence of absence
Authenticity and honesty (both with oneself and with other people)
Platinum Rule >>> Golden Rule: Treat others the way THEY would like to be treated. Abiding by the Golden Rule places your expectations onto other people, and that's a common source of conflict in society
üí≠ I Spend a Lot of Time Thinking About
The balance between self-acceptance and self-improvement
The Dunning‚ÄìKruger effect and, in particular, how it applies to understanding myself
Parenting and education: I have extremely contrarian views on these topics, ranging from wanting many humans of varying ages contributing to childcare (so not just a nuclear family, and definitely not just a nanny while the parents are obsessing over their careers) to believing that traditional schooling is a huge misprioritization of what‚Äôs actually important for kids to learn
Energy work, spirituality, healing, plant medicine, and altered states of consciousness‚Äîand how they all are interconnected for me
The Midwit Meme: One of the most helpful developments growing up weird has been the realization that the modal (/most popular) opinion is by definition not the most informed one
Understanding my edge: This isn't meant at all in a cut-throat competitive manner, but it's more like, if I have a disagreement with an opinion, I'll want to identify why my opinion has merit, what other people are missing, etc. Usually, this means I'll default to those who I think know more than me and not deviate much from these priors based on my own limited experiences, but sometimes, this means I'll have extremely contrarian opinions. (See my poorly executed exercise analogy as an example)
Misaligned incentives: For example, the healthcare industry (and in particular, big pharma) doesn't get paid for treating diseases; they get paid for managing the symptoms. Understanding this is essential to understanding the difference between lifespan and healthspan
The many different ways society perpetuates the status of the American aristocracy and how money in politics takes power away from the people
How oftentimes (especially after thinking about the prior two points), I just want to leave society and live on a farm with the important people in my life
The teachings of Thomas Bayes, William of Ockham, and Robert J. Hanlon: For example, it's extremely probable Epstein didn't kill himself
üî• Favorites
Hobbies üõ∂:  deep conversations about anything; being out in nature (especially activities that involves boat-like apparatuses because I don't exactly float in the water); basketball; board/card games
Books üìö:  Anxious People; My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry; Civilized to Death; Sex at Dawn; Antifragile; The Black Swan; The Scout Mindset; The Biggest Bluff; The Untethered Soul; The Highly Sensitive Person; Nonviolent Communication
TV Shows üì∫:  The Good Place; Crazy Ex-Girlfriend; Sex Education; Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt; Atypical; As We See It; Modern Love; Ted Lasso; Strange Planet (basically anything that makes me both laugh and cry, although it's not difficult to do either)
Food üòã: All of it but especially sushi. One of my in-progress goals is to eat less meat (and probably animal products in general), but giving up seafood would be the most difficult part
Board/card games üÉè: Codenames. It's accessible for non board-game-fanatics and quick enough to not be a multi-hour ordeal. Historically, I've been extremely into more complex strategy games (i.e. Agricola), but my enthusiasm for repetitively grinding these games to try to perfect a strategy has definitely waned. Besides, is there a hunter-gatherer version of Agricola? Accumulating resources in an attempt to grow indefinitely just doesn't get me going like it used to‚Ä¶
I love all water activities
Best show ever!
Find someone who looks at you like‚Ä¶
üëÄ Fun (no, really!) Facts About Me!
I'm passionate about learning in general (especially about how/what/why people think) but am even more passionate about sharing everything I learn with other people (but having to tone it down because no, my friends don't always want to read 500-word essays on obscure niche topics, since no one is as excited about the brain's default mode network, the viability of gift economies, or basketball analytics as me. But in the one-in-a-million chance that you are... you know what to do...)
I both practice time-restricted eating (usually a 6-7 hour window) and eat 60+ pieces of sushi at AYCE sushi. I‚Äôm looking to do a longer fast at some point, but that calling hasn't arrived just yet
I love sharing stories, but I'm also an especially confusing story-teller. There's often really no logical/linear order to my tales. In addition, my sentences will often have way too many clauses, because I get distracted way too easily while simultaneously maintaining the desire to finish my original thought
I once memorized 75 digits of Pi in 1 week during a high school math class simply because I was bored (and the 75 digits were taped to the wall), and I could probably still do it now if I were given an hour to prepare. On the other hand, if I get introduced to more than 1 person at a time at a social gathering, I won't be able to remember a single name. I've been known to refer to people by descriptors until it becomes too cumbersome to say "my friend's sister's boyfriend" repeatedly in a story. Especially if he also has a sister.
One could probably play bingo with the catch phrases I routinely utilize. Some of the words one might include on said bingo card: ‚Äúincentivized‚Äù, ‚Äúsocietal‚Äù, ‚Äústatus goals‚Äù, ‚Äúevolved‚Äù, ‚Äúmidwit‚Äù, ‚Äúright-tailed‚Äù/‚Äùleft-tailed‚Äù, ‚Äúzero-sum‚Äù, ‚Äúsubconsciously‚Äù, ‚Äúthreshold‚Äù, ‚Äúconfidence-level‚Äù, ‚Äúupdate [one's] priors‚Äù.

Date Jos√©
I am looking for someone to date and eventually marry!
Ultimately finding someone is very simple: It‚Äôs just about being mutually attracted and excited about the possibility of building a life together (though you can also reach out for a less intense relationship!). The core requirements for that are:
We must be good communicators (Which in turn requires emotional competency, self-awareness, kindness, curiosity, and intelligence)
We must be mutually attracted (I‚Äôm straight)
And we must vibe
I hope you can judge communication from my writings and the kinds of things I do; attraction from my pictures. The vibe has to be experienced but unlike pictures, that doesn‚Äôt scale. So this document tries to convey my vibe through an explanation of my values, my life, and some anecdotes.
Me on the internet
Show; don‚Äôt tell, as they say:
TwitterJos√© Luis Ric√≥n Fern√°ndez de la Puente (@ArtirKel) on X‚Äã
Instagram (@jlriconf)‚Äã
Jose Luis RiconNintil‚Äã
About me
I was born in Spain (Madrid) in 1992, then grew up in the Canary Islands to a height of 5‚Äô10‚Äô‚Äô. Eventually I went to college for too long, earning two masters degrees in mechanical engineering and aerospace dynamics.
My early career ambitions of doing actual rocket science got derailed by Life, and ended up in a series of jobs that started in the shop floor of an electric car company, an ended up in my current role as Head of Theory at Retro Biosciences. In between I worked at an AI startup that got acquired by Twitter and was offered a job to blog on the internet for 2 years by a bay area benefactor, which also got me my first O1 visa to come to the US. I‚Äôve been a resident of San Francisco for 4 years and intend to continue residing in the Bay Area for the foreseeable future.
This is indeed my official pic from work, see it at retro.bio/team
ALT
To some people I‚Äôm most known as the blogger behind nintil.com, where I‚Äôve written about all sorts of things for over a decade, from the economic history of the USSR to Alzheimer‚Äôs Disease to technological progress and metascience to AI risk. If my current life arc goes well, my next proudest achievement will be to have made a meaningful dent on human aging.
Values
What makes a person them? One could gesture at memories, the way they look, the things they like. Maybe people don‚Äôt really exist, if one has ripped deep from the Parfitian bong. I find some truth to the idea that people are to some extent their values. I definitely think so for myself: I identify with my values, the most stable part of who I am. What do you care about? How do you behave in the world? Here are my own
Truth-seeking: I want to understand the world and those around me, including myself. This is probably the first value I ever consciously endorsed. My first answer to ‚Äúwhat is the point of it all‚Äù was this, perhaps oddly as many people tend to reach for ‚Äòhappiness‚Äô, ‚Äòunderstanding‚Äô.
Honesty and transparency: I really try to only speak truths and to not decline questions about myself, my motivations, or my thoughts (unless there are concerns about other people‚Äôs privacy, promises I‚Äôve made, NDAs, etc). I once stood in front of an audience exposed to arbitrary questions about what most would consider very personal matters and I answered them all.
Reliability: I do what I say. I keep my promises, am not late to things. I keep most of my tasks in my calendar and have good awareness of what‚Äôs happening and what has to happen next.
Integrity: I strive to be consistent in my actions across contexts. No matter what I‚Äôm doing, the same principles apply. If I‚Äôm being hypocritical I appreciate if I‚Äôm called out on it so I can be better aligned with what deep down I value.
Self-improvement: Though I‚Äôm pretty great, I believe I can be even better and I appreciate when others help me, even when I don‚Äôt ask for it. Unsolicited advice is hereby declared solicited!
Benevolent perspective: Sometimes people make other people feel bad for a variety of reasons. I think people are, deep down, good. When they are not, they are mistaken in some or another way. This leads me to react with curiosity, pity, and sadness (accordingly, case by case) instead of anger and hate. I don‚Äôt always act like this for I too am a fallible human but I try! This doesn‚Äôt mean I‚Äôm naive about people. Some people can‚Äôt be trusted, they say one thing and do anther or are manipulative!
Politics: though I don‚Äôt think about politics that much in my day to day life, the labels libertarian, classical libertarian, or even anarchist of some flavor would fit me; you can read more in my blog about my views.
What my life looks like
I live in San Francisco and I really like the Bay Area. I don‚Äôt envision moving anywhere else, particularly as long as I work at my current job. If forced to choose another place (other than the Bay Area), that would be New York.
I‚Äôm the Head of Theory at Retro Biosciences, a company that aims to extend healthy human lifespan by 10 years. I work on strategy and vision-setting for the whole company.
Sometimes after work I have time for some social occasions but I try to have those happening on the weekends. I have a car so nowhere in the bay feels too far.
I go to sauna+cold plunge for ~2 hours every week to unwind and reset for the next week
I go dancing often, either solo (ecstatic dance) or partnered (fusion dance typically). From time to time it is the case that I‚Äôm the first person starting a dance floor. I do contact improv from time to time and I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if I get into tango at some point.
Food remains a passion of mine, it truly is one of the existential joys in life! I like going for dinners and fine dining and occasionally cook. I started hosting dinners for friends this year and would want to host social gatherings in the future
I am very social. There are people out there that probably think of me as their local Partiful dealer.
I go to festivals sometimes; in 2024 I went to vibeclipse, vibecamp, and burning man
But I‚Äôm still an introvert at heart. I like staying in cozymaxxing, drinking tea and reading
This year I picked up meditation and circling and various attempts at embodiment practices. I haven‚Äôt jhana‚Äôd yet but trying!
I do less travel than I used to but I could imagine getting back into it in the future. There is a world out there to explore!
I work out at home. I started building a minigym in my room and would like to expand it if I had more space. Sometimes I go to more class-type workouts like Barry‚Äôs.
I still read and write in my blog, but less than I used to. Now I do a lot of reading and writing at work so that need gets met there.
If I were to write a section like this 5 years ago I‚Äôd say that my life looks like working, going to nice restaurants, occasionally visiting European countries on the weekends, playing videogames, watching anime, reading, and writing in my blog and not feature much in terms of in person social activities. Maybe 5 years from now I‚Äôll be making art, practicing BJJ, and starting my own company.
Potential incompatibilities
Some things that could lead to disagreements or conflicts

If you feel from the bottom of your heart in your relationship that you are not regarded as you should be, I hope you have the courage and dignity to break off such an unhappy relationship. True love does not come between two people who smother each other; it can only come between two strong people who are sure of their individuality. A superficial person will only have superficial relationships. If you want to experience true love, it is important first to sincerely develop a strong identity. True love is certainly not doing what the other person wants, or trying to be what you are not. If someone loves you deeply, he or she will never push you to act against your will or involve you in anything dangerous for you.
Daisaku Ikeda

Hello! I‚Äôm Jon, and I‚Äôm looking for a wife! I‚Äôd love to find a nuanced thinker to have adventures, create and raise a kid or two, and conduct a 50 year conversation that never stops being interesting. If that might be you, and the description below sounds intriguing, get in touch!
üéÇ

Questions I‚Äôm likely to ask you on a first date
I‚Äôm not much for small talk; here‚Äôs a sampling of the kind of thing I‚Äôll want to talk about if we go on a date.
What‚Äôs your heresy? Or put differently, what‚Äôs an opinion you hold that a community you consider yourself a member of would consider anathema?
When‚Äôs the last time you changed your mind about something important?
What‚Äôs something you‚Äôre an expert in? Like top 1% globally?
If you were empress of NYC for a day, what change or policy would you enact to make it a better city for the next 100 years? Think about actual policy levers, not magic-wand sorts of things.
Tell me a story about a trip you took that taught you most about yourself (or reality)
Who are your heroes? Who do you routinely read/pay attention to?
What do you aspire to?
Things I‚Äôve accomplished (roughly chronologically)
In 7th grade I won the City of Madison spelling bee. I still resent  ‚Äúpica‚Äù, the word I lost on at the state competition, as well as ‚Äúpika‚Äù - the adorable animal homonym - out of spite.
Me (second from right) coordinating with local counterparts.
ALT
In my final year of undergrad, I redesigned a water supply system in Ecuador. After graduation, I flew down with my team and built it! We organized ~400 volunteers over a week and a half to enlarge sections of pipe, install valves and meters, and restore equitable access to a water supply system that served 5 villages in the hills above Otovalo. I also managed a sewer project in El Salvador through Engineers Without Borders.
I spent 2 years living and working in Uganda as a Peace Corps Volunteer. While there, I started this company, still operating - some of my proudest work!
Started a machine-learning startup (now defunct) with my best friend
One of my favorite economists, Arnold Kling, ran a Fantasy Intellectual Teams competition. I am the undefeated champion
When I went to Azerbaijan in 2023, I enjoyed their national dish (Shakh Plov) so much, I taught myself how to make it when I came home.
Interests
Reading See below for my ‚Äúholy canon‚Äù, but I‚Äôm constantly reading great sci-fi or history related to an upcoming trip
Travel I‚Äôm in an informal competition with my dad to visit the most countries. My current count is 50. This year (2024) I‚Äôm planning trips to Peru, Bolivia, Brazil, Taiwan, China, Poland, Germany, Czechia, Austria and maybe Pakistan. In 2023 I visited Senegal, Norway, Turkey, Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Sweden, Hungary, and Slovakia.
Uncle-ing It‚Äôs my great honor to be ‚ÄúUncle Jon‚Äù to 3 kids of my close friends. I can‚Äôt wait to be a dad of my own, but in the meantime I take great delight in being the funcle.
Board games  Every August I buy (and get mildly obsessed with) that year‚Äôs board game of the year, and I host a monthly-ish gathering of friends for food and games.
Road trips/camping/hiking My trusty steed (above) is named Dawn Treader, and she is the finest roadtripmobile in all the land. We have ~50,000 miles together. I‚Äôll never say no to a new national park, though I indulged that hobby a bit more when I lived in Seattle.
Beauty I try to bring something beautiful back from every country I visit, and infuse a small bit of what caught my eye there into some part of my daily life. Sometimes it‚Äôs a painting, or a knicknack for my shelf, or a recipe I learn. Very often, my aesthetic taste inclines toward the hexagonal.
Attributes/Things that I am
Engineer. I hold a masters degree in Civil Engineering, and though I‚Äôve long since turned my career to IT Product Leadership, I still think of myself fundamentally as a problem-solver and builder.
Emotionally Stable I‚Äôm reliable and steadfast - even on my crappiest of days, I stick to my values and show up for my important relationships.
Adventurous  ‚Ä¶but not an adrenaline junky. I haven‚Äôt jumped out of any perfectly good airplanes, but I‚Äôm 70% sure I could land one in an emergency. Exploring the unknown (in a city, in a country, in a woman, in the past) lights me up. These words from Tennyson resonate with me:
‚ÄúI am a part of all that I have met;
Yet all experience is an arch wherethro'
Gleams that untravell'd world whose margin fades
For ever and forever when I move.
How dull it is to pause, to make an end,
To rust unburnish'd, not to shine in use!‚Äù
Minimalist Twice I‚Äôve shrunk my possessions down to what could fit in my car. I also take enormous joy in finding the perfect object of any kind - be it travel shoe, backpack, or camping equipment. I can comfortably travel for 5 weeks with only a 10lb backpack.
Values
Curiosity - There is very little that disinterests me. I particularly love encountering new phenomenon and learning all I can about it. One of my favorites is to pair reading with my travel - brushing up on the last thousand years or so of that place, trying to figure out what makes it special.
Loyalty  - My 5 oldest friendships are an average of 20 years old. When I find people I Iike, I do all I can to build durable relationships.
Pragmatic Incrementalism - If I have an overriding philosophy, it‚Äôs this. A little bit better today is better than a lot better maybe never. Move at the margin, the perfect is the enemy of the good, get 80% of returns from 20% of inputs, compounding returns are your friend.
Enlightenment Values - Steven Pinker‚Äôs ‚ÄúEnlightenment Now‚Äù is on my holy books list because it‚Äôs been profoundly influential to my thought. I‚Äôd like a partner who shares (or at least enthusiastically tolerates) my belief in the idea of an abundant future. My desired political outcomes skew to the neo-liberal. In the US, I‚Äôm politically homeless but especially tribeless, and I proudly identify as a heretic.
Nuance - I strive to be an independent, first-principles thinker. I split hairs with wild abandon. I pay attention to dozens of writers, podcasters, youtubers, and academics - none of whom I agree with on all topics. I‚Äôm much more interested in a thriving intellectual atmosphere where outstanding participants can debate in good faith. The GMU economics department is my favorite idea lab.
What I‚Äôd like to bring to/create in a relationship
Permanence - I‚Äôm looking for a partner for the rest of my life. I was married before (happy to talk about what happened, but not on the internet), but I‚Äôm serious about finding one person to grow old with. I‚Äôm a believer in the committed, monogamous relationship both for raising kids as well as building a relationship that works for us both.
Goodness - One of my fundamental relationship values/aspirations is that partners should be as good to each other as they can possibly manage. I‚Äôd like us to be one of those couples that amasses such a wealth of good will aimed at each other that it becomes contagious, a beautiful bubble of relationship somewhat insulated from reality but still embedded in it such that we bend the universe around us. I don‚Äôt need or desire that relationship to be all-consuming, but I want it to be strong and stable enough to survive (and even thrive in) the demand of our future toddler(s) that the universe revolve around them.  I think few people would openly disagree with this sentiment, but I mean it in the deepest possible sense. I‚Äôm looking for a relationship where we are both seriously committed to co-creating a life full of joy for each other, and that means taking our differences seriously, and getting really good at negotiating shared and separate spaces that meet our needs.
Partnership - I‚Äôm open to most manifestations of roles in child rearing/household management and income generation. I‚Äôm actively looking forward to being a father and supportive partner. Ideally we‚Äôd have a 30-70% overlap in shared interests such that its enjoyable to be together ‚Äúby default‚Äù.
Get in touch!
If this sounds interesting to you, get in touch! I‚Äôm not looking for a long distance relationship (i.e. it‚Äôd be great if you‚Äôre in NYC) but maybe you‚Äôre the one to convince me otherwise.

About me

ALT
I‚Äôm a co-founder of Impact Academy - a non-profit that runs ambitious educational programs to enable young people to use their careers to solve some of the most pressing problems and contribute to a better future. I also work as a coach for impact-driven people. I enjoy communal living and have lived in multiple group houses -  including one with a six-month-old baby, but am also open to other forms of communal living.
Before that, I did a bunch of different things throughout my life. I trained as a medical doctor, did biosecurity research at Stanford that might have contributed a tiny bit to the prevention of pandemics, co-founded Effective Altruism Denmark, co-authored a book during my undergrad, and created a course for 1000+ students.
I‚Äôm also a mediocre salsa dancer and a non-terrible singer (who loves to sing Alicia Keys songs). On the more adventurous side, I've spent four months in Nepal and hitchhiked from Copenhagen to Budapest.
My journey
Due to luck and a great teacher, I had a wake-up call when I was 16 and I realized that I was on a bad trajectory. I started to work on forming my values, character, and lifestyle to take care of myself and lead a more meaningful and altruistic life (such as supporting refugees). As I was deciding on my degree, I considered many different options (from social science to philosophy) as I‚Äôm very curious (and still am! üôÇ). However, I narrowed it down to medicine and psychology and eventually decided on medicine as I thought it was the most promising way of understanding the human condition and thus help others the most. Especially those who needed it the most. This was mainly driven by altruism, curiosity, and unnoticed guilt.
During the first years of my undergrad, I co-authored a¬†book¬†with a Norwegian author who had inspired me when I was younger. The book we wrote together was on how to study effectively and I was later hired to create and teach a course for all medical students at my university. I eventually decided to pivot away from this because I believed effective altruism and global health were more important (not an easy decision!). I had several existential crises and almost dropped out to join Effective Giving when it was starting out. However, I decided to finish the degree and build the EA community in Denmark (which I did for three years next to med school). During these later years, I also started finding ‚Äúmy people,‚Äù with whom I built deep friendships that last to this day, frequently bringing me joy and gratitude.
Towards the end of med school, I ran a career experiment in biosecurity at Stanford University, SSI, and the US CDC for two years. My research was on mortality monitoring using¬†EuroMOMO¬†because I predicted it‚Äôd be useful in pandemics (pre-covid). This included living in an incredible group house with entrepreneurs in Palo Alto and trying coaching. These experiences introduced me more seriously to entrepreneurship and coaching - both of which I‚Äôve been pursuing since 2020. In 2022, I had the fortune of meeting some awesome and like-minded people who had a similar vision so we co-founded Impact Academy.
Me facilitating a workshop at a conference. (2019)

My decade vision
I have three main ambitions for this decade (until December 31st, 2030):
Make Impact Academy a world-class organization that runs ambitious educational programs to enable people to use their careers to solve some of the most pressing problems and contribute to a better future.
Find the other half of an altruistic couple - a "romantic co-founder". Someone who wants to co-create a beautiful relationship where we can support each other in our missions to create a better world, grow, and create beautiful experiences. This could involve starting a family.
Be a coach for some of the most impactful individuals and enable them to enhance their lifetime impact, become their best selves, and care for themselves and their loved ones.

About you
Below is my current hypothesis for what I‚Äôm looking for in a partner. If most of this resonates, then we might be a great match, though (in all honesty) you may be too good for me. üòä Don‚Äôt worry about ‚Äúticking all of the boxes‚Äù - the most important thing is that most of these resonate with you. Qualities and tendencies
Important stuff
We will likely be a good match if most of the following qualities are important to you.
Ethical and on an ambitious mission to make the world better.
You have a drive to make the world a better place and have used this as your guiding star during most of your important life decisions. You have engaged with several moral theories, and you likely find some form of consequentialism the most plausible, though you appreciate other theories. You might be particularly devoted to the betterment of future generations or think that the alleviation of suffering is more important than the promotion of happiness. You‚Äôve probably been inspired by Effective Altruism (though may have significant reservations), but you‚Äôre at least positive about the core principles of wanting to improve the world and using reason and evidence.
Intellectual and curious.
You find great joy in understanding things by using a scientific mindset. Holding accurate beliefs is much more important than being right to you. You‚Äôve changed your mind on important issues, which led to you taking action, too. Even though it was weird or unconventional. You enjoy trying new things, are likely an avid reader, and find long (3 hours+) conversations enjoyable.
Growth-oriented and perhaps even a bit wise.
Growing as a person and becoming wiser is important to you. For many years, you‚Äôve probably done things such as i) reflecting on your values, strengths, and weaknesses, ii) trying to optimize/systematize your life, and iii) cultivating virtues such as humility and kindness. You may have read books like Man‚Äôs Search For Meaning, The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People, and Peak and have habits like meditation, journaling, and tracking. You probably also love facilitating this for others.
Globally-minded (Cosmopolitan)
You‚Äôre globally minded and care about global affairs - from the more substantive and difficult to the lighthearted. For example, you‚Äôll happily engage in a discussion on the relationship between the US and China and appreciate cultivating friendships with people from different cultures.
Loving and affectionate yet strong and emotionally stable
You‚Äôre caring and attentive to the needs of others. You‚Äôd sense whether I‚Äôm happy or sad and make me feel cared for via your words and actions (and emojis ‚ò∫Ô∏è). Bonus points if one of your love languages is physical touch. That being said, you have a fairly deep sense of who you are and some level of self-compassion. Consequently, you don‚Äôt let others‚Äô perspectives and needs crowd out yours so you can set boundaries and express disagreements when you think it‚Äôs right.

At the highest level, I want us to co-create a beautiful partnership where we can support and inspire each other in our missions to create a better world while learning, building relationships/communities, and enjoying life. This will require experimentation, work, and direct communication.
Based on my previous relationships, I‚Äôd love to do some of these things together:

This is a picture from an intentional reading event I co-hosted. (2023)

Past relationships
I‚Äôm grateful for the previous romantic relationships I‚Äôve been part of, and I think all of them are wonderful people. However, they didn‚Äôt work for some important reasons, and it‚Äôs valuable to learn from them. Here are some reasons why it didn‚Äôt work (work in progress).
What I felt was missing (in some or all of the relationships):
Not enough altruism and/or dedication.
Felt I was the one who was taking the initiative and helping us grow
Not being into intense intellectual conversations.

Them not liking long distance and/or us moving for professional reasons. I don‚Äôt love long-distance, but I can be happy while being apart if the initial base is there.

But really, my goal is to find a loving, rewarding relationship with a female I am interested in and for whom I am willing to sacrifice the time necessary to build a relationship. Someone who is kind, intelligent, silly, curious, courageous, and empathetic. And very importantly, someone who is emotionally mature enough to realize the kind of work and sacrifices that a relationship entails.
I am pretty flexible about the actual location, since my job is usually remote. Buttt I am a sucker for good weather - I‚Äôve lived in the Bay Area for most of my life and in Malaga, Spain for a little bit so I am not going to pretend that living in Norway would be perfect for me. The culinary arts have captured my fascination, leading me to experiment with a myriad of flavors and cuisines. üç≥ This mirrors my approach to life itself ‚Äì a constant experimentation and blending of diverse elements.
Trekking through nature's wonders and hitchhiking along the road less traveled are pursuits that invigorate my spirit. The thrill of the unknown and the allure of discovery guide my steps, both in the wilderness and in the world of tech. üèûÔ∏èüöó
Seeking a Like-Minded  Adventurer:
As I continue to traverse the intersections of technology, travel, and taste, I am on the lookout for a kindred spirit. An individual who, like me, revels in the sensory pleasures of gourmet delights, craves the thrill of uncharted destinations, and finds solace in the pages of a well-worn book.
So, if your heart beats to the rhythm of exploration, if your taste buds tingle at the mere mention of exotic flavors, and if your mind eagerly absorbs knowledge like a sponge, then perhaps we are destined to embark on a shared journey through the digital and physical landscapes that lie before us.
My love languages are quality time and personal touch! I‚Äôm pretty independent and self-sufficient, but I love hanging out and spending downtime with my loved ones. I also would love for someone to encourage my more spontaneous side!
Let's connect and embrace the adventure together! ü§ù

I resonate with the Infinite Finite Games book (summary by Farnam Street). I love trying out different things and observing how I feel. I am very self-aware and think a lot. Trying to cultivate thinking for myself as my default state of being.
Curiosity & intelligence
I have a lot of energy and am deeply curious. You will likely sense it from our first IRL convo. For now, check out¬†this link. (Btw I love curius). Also, wanna try lots of things in my life: https://www.svitlana.me/curiosities.
Spirituality & interest in the eastern religions/philosophy
I have been wondering about spiritual-like topics for 3 years now. Some questions are: what is reality? who am I and what is self?
The real hunger for spiritual understanding accelerated when russia invaded my home. Check then news on Ukraine. To help myself cope, I have been reading a lot. I think I found some sense equanimity and peace  now that is  becoming more and more present. I meditate, do yoga, breath work, cold plunges on a regular basis.
Movement
At first a coping mechanism, movement now grew into me. I need it and do it often. Not necessarily restricting moving to gym, a square of grass or yoga mat is great too. My goals are handstands, crow pose, pull-ups and flexibility/mobility.

I regret not doing sports in my adolescence as now there is so much work to be done to get to what I want (e.g. I want handstands and it is hard on both physical and inner-work levels). What my friends say: borshch
It is hard to have an objective evaluation of a human being, so I found borshch to be the closest proxy for estimating quality of me as future wife.
Borshch is a Ukrainian soup that takes ~2-3 hours to make and is often cooked as a test for marriage readiness. A wife (yes wife, not a man bc men do not cook!!!) is only as good as her borshch (ah, what a great way to reduce human complexity:).
My friend said, ‚Äúthe caliber of a person is determined not by any single borscht they cooked, but that they keep cooking borscht. It is the borscht of the soul that makes the borscht of the stomach.‚Äù
I fed my friends with borshch and asked some follow-up qs.

I'm short, monogamous, and usually dressed in an alarmingly varied array of colors:
(me, doing things)
(me, still doing things)
(me, doing something I will definitely never do again)
I'd regale you with tales of my wanderings, but they're honestly quite boring and involve a lot of pet lab mice and early internet fanfic for some reason. The gist of it is that some combination of temperament, parental upbringing, and early Shounen Jump issues led to the dorky, egregiously friendly Huffleclaw you see before yourself today. In my bursts of social fancy I love flittering around novel/weird/interesting-sounding events, philosophy salons, and mysterious houseparties in the Bay, but I'm really an introvert at the core who likes to sun by big windows and nerd out on whatever topic has struck her this week (in my previous life I was definitely a cat, just one of those weirdo bodega ones that like people :P).
I recharge my batteries on all the cozy things - longreads, podcasts, indie movies, coffeeshops and kava bars, bookshops with that old-book smell and perky plants, dinner parties, morning runs by the water and game nights with friends - but will absolutely get hype for the periodic rave, music festival, or good-lord-what-have-I-gotten-myself-into party. I'm high on the openness scale and enjoy poking at new things - even (especially) if they sound a bit out of my comfort zone - though my hope this year is to run around a little less, figure out the things I really care about, and go all in on the people and pursuits that matter to me. Who knows? That could be you üòâ
A few pluses about me:
no kids, debt, or crazy exes
likes doing dishes and laundry because that's podcast time üëå
prefers homey restaurants over fancy ones so cheap date
speaks Mandarin so kids will be set up for the future üí™
pretty good at charming old people so your parents will like me
not addicted to tiktok or insta üòÉ (but addicted to reddit instead üòî)
decent meme game, if I do say so myself üòé
My current obsessions in this ‚Äújust left the city I was in for a decade, hashtag yolo‚Äù phase of my life look something like training for a half-marathon, finally learning meditation (or similar in that vein), working on some AI side projects, researching for the book series I keep swearing I'll write, discovering more substacks to hoard in my email, spending a horrifying amount of time on soccer chats (long-suffering Spurs fan here‚Ä¶ don't ask üôà), and making my new home in SF. If I were to pick the one "thing" that really moves me, it'd be the idea of community and how we can better invigorate our society and the platforms we use to foster meaningful relationships, chances for connection, any form of antidote to loneliness that's a little less toxic than some of the tribes that have been forming online. I don't have good answers there but it's a subject I'm very interested in and would love to pick folks' brains on - so if you know anyone engaging in that sphere, I'd be all ears! üòä
What I'm looking for
A thoughtful, kind, kick-ass dude in either SF or NYC also looking for a life partner, a pet or two, and somewhere within one standard deviation of 2.5 kids (I was an only child and I think a sibling-less childhood just really sucks! I want to make a really fun household üòù).
I'm super into a rigorous, analytical mind (though perhaps less in the sense of traditional booksmarts than street smarts, or a way of thinking outside the box) and curious, driven people who are always looking to learn and grow. I‚Äôve matched well with honest, assertive, maybe even slightly disagreeable partners who aren't afraid to call me out on things and can balance me out as a teammate (I'll play good cop to your bad cop! The Agent J to your K. The Leslie to your Ron Swanson etc), but I also love goofballs who‚Äôll text me a terrible meme at 4 in the morning. It‚Äôs stereotypical but oftentimes I think I‚Äôm just looking for someone who makes me laugh üòÖ¬†whose values also make me want to be a better person.
I like sporty people. I like nerdy people. I like people who care; I think I'd take that over super ‚Äúcool‚Äù people, as much as I am awed by their badassery sometimes. I love finding the life in people - passion is just delightful! (Even if it's mainly for fantasy football or large language models üòÜ). I can talk your ear off when I'm in the mood, but I LOVE people who can match my energy in conversation and even steer it or relieve my burden when I'm tired; and I think it's a great sign when we can do our own thing in companionable silence and enjoy that too.
Above all else though, I think personal integrity and, like, just giving a shit about people is sine qua non. How someone treats people, whether they keep their word, whether they can navigate the hard times with a steadiness of mind and character is so much more important imho than a few extra points on the IQ scale or zeros in the bank account. I feel the exact same way about close friends, which is why I call my dream life partner as "basically a best friend I'm attracted to and want to raise a family with" - some undefinable formula whose variables are a permutation of friendship, passion, and mutual respect.
Honestly though, I could go on and on rambling here about a shared sense of humor, high bonding-ness, and a level of introversion that agrees to escape a party at the same time, but I do think most of this you're just never going to get off paper because it's really, like, all about the vibes, man. That's not to say dealbreakers don't exist or that compatibility is wholly unpredictable, but I really like waitbutwhy's take on it - a huge part of it is about who you really enjoy being around, and most of that time won't be romantic dates but grocery shopping and waiting for the bus and blobbing on the couch after work. You want someone you enjoy all the times in between the big vacations and dream travel destinations and Burning Mans with - someone you enjoy cooking dinner on the thousandth Wednesday with, or waiting for the Uber with, or rambling about your day to at the end of a long work week. Most of life is the mundane stuff in between the cool exciting stuff, so I'm looking for someone who I can have a mind-boggling amount of fun just Doordashing and watching Celebrity Family Feud with. That's rather difficult to figure out through a few paragraphs and a photo, so really, if this speaks out to you and we seem like a good match - hit me up and let's grab coffee?
Lifestyle compatibility
In a burst of abandon I once signed up for a matchmaking service (note: this did not land me on a Netflix reality show sadly, though it did get me a bunch of spam calls for a year after). The service did not work out as you can probably tell, but what I found interesting about it was that a solid 90% of the intake questions I had to answer was on my lifestyle. I'm not kidding - a quarter might have been about my sleeping habits alone (how late I slept, whether I was a light sleeper, if I needed space in the bed etc).
That has made me think a bit more about lifestyle fit. Having great dates with someone doesn't mean it's easy to live with them, and the latter gets much more important in a serious relationship. I'm sure plenty of folks might not put much stock in any of these, but just in case, I'll list some lifestyle traits of mine upfront:
I'm more of a city gal than a super outdoorsy person, though I do run outdoors almost every day and enjoy a scenic hike or two (and I absolutely love parks!). My favored travel destinations lean towards cities and cultural/historical attractions more than extreme nature spots. Basically I'd pick reading in a cafe or visiting the Louvre over heavy-duty camping most of the time, though I‚Äôm absolutely down for festivals in the woods and cabin trips with  friends.
Long-term I also want to stay around a major city, preferably SF or NYC since my social circles are here and my driving skills are uh, stereotypical at best üòÖ¬†Having said that, I definitely understand the space + cost trade-off of living in those cities.
I'm not a huge gamer, though I've played a few RPGs and enjoy word-based boardgames and co-ops; and as you can tell from the Comic-Con pics, I‚Äôm a long-time anime/manga fan and geek out on a lot of things across the board (scifi, Doctor Who, Marvel etc).
I drink socially, and it‚Äôd be nice if my partner could join me there though it‚Äôs not a big deal by any means. I'm not a huge foodie or picky but I do try to eat healthily (in moderation!) and am omnivorous with a plant-based lean. It doesn't matter to me if my partner's a serious foodie or vegan or has a lot of restrictions, though if their main hobby is food (e.g. eating out at fancy restaurants every other day) I wouldn‚Äôt be able to share in it.
Politically, I'm generally progressive, though eclectically so since I prefer to evaluate an issue in its own context instead of feeling boxed into one broad political platform. I'm open to partners on other parts of the spectrum, as long as there's still a values alignment.
Financially, I try to be pretty frugal on consumables (I don‚Äôt eat expensive meals or buy $400 purses) but will absolutely spend money on what I think of as investments: a high-end laptop, Lasik, a course I‚Äôm interested in, anything that makes me more productive at work. I care about experiences, especially the ones best done now (it‚Äôs hard to travel when old!) but I think tangible goods have their place in making your life better. Basically, my heuristic is to value the things that will buy me more time with friends. ‚ù§Ô∏è
I‚Äôd like at least some time to myself most days; I think it's important for couples to have their own hobbies, though I do enjoy parallel play. I don't need my partner to go to everything with me - I can get into really social butterfly moods and if anything I'd much more appreciate having someone to come home to! Later on in a relationship, I'd love a little check-in text/call on days we're apart.
Speaking of - I do love texting üôà Not a huge deal to me if you don't, but some form of communication most days is pretty important to me. I'd be amped to have someone I can send both serious longreads and dumb twitter memes to, though I don't think there's a need to have a bunch of the same interests - it's more about a similar sense of humor and an interest in the other's life.
My love language is literally conversation, though I might file that more under quality time and companionship than words of affirmation. I love fussing over people and end up doing a lot of acts of service, and the Chinese heritage in me likes to say words are cheap, but my last relationship made me realize how much I value open affection. That's both physical and verbal - I can barely remember what I ate yesterday but almost never forget what someone says to me, for both good and bad (this is NOT to say I demand sappy love letters, just that a sincere word spoken in kindness goes a long way with me üòä).
Hit me up?
First of all, you're the bomb if you actually read this far. And if this clicks with you and you think we might be a good match, hit me up via email, Facebook, or Twitter! If you have a similar kind of profile up somewhere that would be great, otherwise I'd appreciate an intro about yourself and what you're into, what you're looking for, pics or socials etc. Peace! üññ
